grade3-5.example: Break a leg on your school play tonight!
We can't go to the park because it's raining cats and dogs.
You failed the test, but don't cry over spilled milk. Study harder next time.
The math homework was a piece of cake for Sarah.

grade3-5.idiom: Don't count your chickens before they hatch
grade3-5.meaning: Don't assume something will happen before it actually does
grade3-5.example: Don't count your chickens before they hatch - wait until you get your test results.

grade3-5.idiom: The early bird catches the worm
grade3-5.meaning: People who wake up early or arrive first get the best opportunities
grade3-5.example: I got to school early and got the best seat. The early bird catches the worm!

grade3-5.idiom: Don't put all your eggs in one basket
grade3-5.meaning: Don't risk everything on one plan
grade3-5.example: Apply to several schools, don't put all your eggs in one basket.
I'll clean my room when pigs fly!
Hold your horses! We need to wait for everyone before we start the game.

grade3-5.meaning: Something or someone difficult to deal with
grade3-5.example: That puzzle is really a piece of work - it's so hard!

grade3-5.idiom: Kill two birds with one stone
grade3-5.example: I'll visit grandma and go to the store - kill two birds with one stone.

grade3-5.idiom: Let the cat out of the bag
grade3-5.example: Don't let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party!

grade3-5.idiom: Like a fish out of water
grade3-5.example: At the fancy restaurant, Tom felt like a fish out of water.
We go to the movies once in a blue moon because it's expensive.
Come on, spill the beans! What did you get me for my birthday?

grade3-5.idiom: The ball is in your court
grade3-5.meaning: It's your turn to make a decision
grade3-5.example: I've made my offer, now the ball is in your court.
I'm feeling under the weather today, so I'll stay home.
A talking dog? You're pulling my leg!
I can't believe summer is over - time flies!

grade3-5.meaning: It's better to do something late than not at all
grade3-5.example: You finally cleaned your room. Better late than never!

grade6-8.meaning: Face a difficult situation bravely
grade6-8.example: I have to bite the bullet and tell my parents about my bad grade.

grade6-8.meaning: Work late into the night
grade6-8.example: I had to burn the midnight oil to finish my science project.

grade6-8.idiom: Don't judge a book by its cover
grade6-8.meaning: Don't form opinions based on appearance alone
grade6-8.example: She looks mean, but don't judge a book by its cover - she's actually very kind.

grade6-8.idiom: Every cloud has a silver lining
grade6-8.meaning: There's something good in every bad situation
grade6-8.example: I broke my leg, but every cloud has a silver lining - now I have time to read.

grade6-8.idiom: Hit the nail on the head
grade6-8.meaning: Be exactly right about something
grade6-8.example: You hit the nail on the head when you said the test would be difficult.

grade6-8.meaning: Join a popular activity or opinion
grade6-8.example: Everyone's buying those shoes, so I jumped on the bandwagon too.

grade6-8.meaning: Stay positive during difficult times
grade6-8.example: I know you're sad about moving, but keep your chin up!

grade6-8.meaning: Don't disturb a situation that's currently peaceful
grade6-8.example: They're not fighting anymore, so let sleeping dogs lie.

grade6-8.idiom: Make a mountain out of a molehill
grade6-8.meaning: Make a small problem seem bigger than it is
grade6-8.example: It's just a small scratch - don't make a mountain out of a molehill.

grade6-8.meaning: Doing something repeatedly makes you better at it
grade6-8.example: Keep playing piano every day - practice makes perfect!

grade6-8.idiom: Rome wasn't built in a day
grade6-8.meaning: Important things take time to accomplish
grade6-8.example: Learning guitar is hard, but Rome wasn't built in a day.

grade6-8.idiom: The grass is always greener on the other side
grade6-8.meaning: Other situations always seem better than your own
grade6-8.example: You think private school is better, but the grass is always greener on the other side.

grade6-8.meaning: What you do is more important than what you say
grade6-8.example: He says he'll help, but actions speak louder than words.

grade6-8.meaning: Something that seems bad but turns out to be good
grade6-8.example: Missing the bus was a blessing in disguise - I found my lost wallet!

grade6-8.meaning: Hope for good luck
grade6-8.example: Cross your fingers that it doesn't rain during our picnic.

grade6-8.meaning: Become nervous about doing something
grade6-8.example: I was going to ask her to the dance, but I got cold feet.

grade6-8.meaning: Study hard
grade6-8.example: I need to hit the books if I want to pass the exam.

grade6-8.meaning: In trouble
grade6-8.example: I'm in hot water with my teacher for not doing homework.

grade6-8.meaning: Watch carefully
grade6-8.example: Keep your eyes peeled for the school bus.

grade6-8.meaning: Very happy
grade6-8.example: She was on cloud nine after getting accepted to her dream school.

grade9-10.meaning: Avoid talking directly about a topic
grade9-10.example: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what happened.

grade9-10.idiom: Bite off more than you can chew
grade9-10.meaning: Take on more than you can handle
grade9-10.example: Taking six AP classes might mean you're biting off more than you can chew.

grade9-10.meaning: Stop working for the day
grade9-10.example: We've been studying for hours - let's call it a day.

grade9-10.meaning: Get to the point quickly
grade9-10.example: Let's cut to the chase - what do you really want?

grade9-10.meaning: Argue the opposite side for the sake of argument
grade9-10.example: I'll play devil's advocate - what if this plan doesn't work?

grade9-10.meaning: Make an extra effort
grade9-10.example: She always goes the extra mile to help her students understand.

grade9-10.meaning: Start something energetically and successfully
grade9-10.example: On her first day at the new school, she hit the ground running.

grade9-10.meaning: In the same difficult situation
grade9-10.example: We're all stressed about finals - we're in the same boat.

grade9-10.meaning: Act too soon or prematurely
grade9-10.example: Don't jump the gun - wait for all the college responses before deciding.

grade9-10.idiom: Keep your cards close to your chest
grade9-10.meaning: Keep your plans or thoughts secret
grade9-10.example: He's keeping his cards close to his chest about which college he'll choose.

grade9-10.idiom: Let the chips fall where they may
grade9-10.meaning: Accept whatever happens as a result of your actions
grade9-10.example: I'm going to tell the truth and let the chips fall where they may.

grade9-10.meaning: Miss an opportunity
grade9-10.example: I missed the boat on applying for that scholarship.

grade9-10.meaning: You must work hard to achieve success
grade9-10.example: Studying is hard, but no pain, no gain - you'll get good grades.

grade9-10.meaning: Calm down and control your emotions
grade9-10.example: Pull yourself together - the presentation isn't that scary.

grade9-10.meaning: Understand the hidden meaning
grade9-10.example: She said she was fine, but reading between the lines, she's upset.

grade9-10.meaning: Take credit for someone else's idea or achievement
grade9-10.example: He stole my thunder by presenting my idea first.

grade9-10.idiom: The ball is in your court
grade9-10.meaning: It's your responsibility to take action
grade9-10.example: I've given you all the information - the ball is in your court now.

grade9-10.meaning: Think creatively and unconventionally
grade9-10.example: This problem needs creative solutions - think outside the box.

grade9-10.meaning: Be very careful about what you say or do
grade9-10.example: Ever since the argument, I've been walking on eggshells around her.

grade9-10.idiom: You can't have your cake and eat it too
grade9-10.meaning: You can't have two good things that contradict each other
grade9-10.example: You can't skip practice and be on the team - you can't have your cake and eat it too.
